items.title: As Russia threats worsen, all Canadians can help security: Latvian envoy
items.description: 'When Russia is lowering the threshold of doing mischief, using force or anything ... it's very worrying,' said Latvia's ambassador to Canada in an interview with Global News.

items.title: Nearly 1 in 10 terrorism investigations at CSIS involves a minor: spy boss
items.description: The head of Canada’s spy agency is warning about a “worrying” number of young people becoming radicalized.

items.title: Family of New Brunswick man who died in hospital emergency room settles lawsuit
items.description: The family of a 78-year-old man who died after waiting seven hours for care in a Fredericton hospital has settled a legal action they filed against the province’s health authority.

items.title: NordicTrack rowing machine recalled in Canada over fire hazard
items.description: The company said it has sold 700 units of the rowing machine in Canada. The affected products were sold from November 2018 to April 2022.

items.title: CSIS director outlines security threats posed by Russia, China, Iran, India
items.description: The director of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service catalogued the espionage and transnational repression efforts of Canada’s adversaries.

items.title: Governments of Canada and Manitoba Launch Pilot to Reward Sustainable Farming
Governments Of Canada and Manitoba Strengthening Justice for Canada's First Responders
How does this year's flu shot stack up to current strains? What we know
items.description: It's flu season in Canada, and as the number of infections and hospitalizations start to rise, medical experts are urging Canadians to get their flu shots.

items.title: CBSA says airport inspection kiosks working again after outage
items.description: The Canada Border Services Agency says some airport inspection kiosks are currently not working due to an outage for maintenance work.

items.title: 60 years later, Nevada homicide victim identified as missing Calgary woman
items.description: Anna Sylvia Just was initially reported missing by her sister after she was last seen boarding a bus in Calgary in 1966. Decades later, her remains have been identified in Nevada.

items.title: B.C. limits when employers can request sick notes
items.description: A government statement says that under new employment standards regulations, an employer can't ask for a note for the first two health-related absences of up to five consecutive days in the same year.

items.title: Manitoba Government Expands Care for Dialysis Patients and Mothers in Norway House Cree Nation
Canada must not back down on industrial carbon price
Why Is It So Hard to Fix a Wheelchair in BC?
items.description: Disabled people say companies are struggling to service their equipment, which can trap them in bed or at home.

items.title: Why The Tragically Hip are lending their songs to Boi-1da ahead of World Cup | Hanomansing Tonight
items.description: The Tragically Hip have given award-winning producer Boi-1da access to the band's entire catalogue for a special project to raise funds for the Canada Soccer Foundation. Rob Baker, guitarist for the Tragically Hip, discusses more about the project.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Solar storms bring dazzling display of northern lights
items.description: Solar storms brought colourful auroras to unexpected southern places in Canada and the United States on Tuesday night — and there could be more to come.

items.title: Manitoba Government Invests More Than $1.3 Million for Community Revitalization Projects in Westman
Workers ‘needed more' from Budget 2025 amidst trade crisis, Labour Congress says
Party Discipline Is Undermining Canadian Democracy
items.description: Alberta’s bill ordering teachers back to work is a prime example, say authors of a new book.

items.title: Manitoba Government Recognizes Inaugural Circle of Honour Recipients
Manitoba Government to Help Students Learn About Climate Change and Climate Action in Schools
Climate organizations across the country disappointed at PM Carney’s 2025 Federal Budget
Ontario to spend $210M on non-speed camera road safety measures following ban
items.description: Ontario Premier Doug Ford's government is earmarking $210 million for municipalities to implement traffic-calming measures as its ban on speed cameras is set to take effect.

items.title: How BC Killed the ‘Last Hope’ for the Deaf Community
items.description: A Tyee Q&A with Deaf advocate Sarah-Anne Hrycenko after an NDP retreat on a plan for change.

items.title: Third Session of the 43rd Manitoba Legislature to Open Tuesday, Nov. 18 with Speech from the Throne
‘I feel it in my bones': Grey Cup anthem singer brings family legacy to big game
items.description: The national anthem at Sunday's Grey Cup championship in Winnipeg will be performed by Manitoba country singer Catie St. Germain, who says she's nervous but excited.

items.title: Art Gallery of Ontario scores major donation of portraits, including Warhol prints
items.description: The Art Gallery of Ontario says it has received a significant gift of more than 450 pieces of art, including works by pop titans Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and David Hockney.

items.title: Slew of recall campaigns in Alberta target UCP politicians
You Nearly Missed: Vancouver roots royalty joins Chest Fever at the Rickshaw for a tribute to the Band's Last Waltz
items.description: Robbie Robertson would definitely approve.

items.title: Photos: Atlanta rapper JID makes the most of a Monday night PNE Forum crowd
items.description: The artist brought the crowd to its feet.

items.title: The Beaches make a play for Canadian rock royalty at Doug Mitchell
items.description: The Beaches are making more than just waves.

items.title: 'Relentless' AFC Toronto set to battle and host 'hard-nosed' Vancouver Rise FC in 1st NSL Final
items.description: The first Northern Super League Final will never be forgotten, regardless of Saturday's outcome. But it could be more memorable if host AFC Toronto and Vancouver Rise FC match the excitement of their respective paths to the Canadian professional women's soccer championship.

items.title: Historic Stampede Ranch once owned by outdoor show's founder facing receivership application hearing
Ottawa seeking a permanent parliamentary budget officer with 'tact and discretion'
items.description: Ottawa says it's looking to hire a permanent parliamentary budget officer — someone with "tact and discretion" — just a few months after appointing a critical fiscal watchdog on an interim basis.

items.title: N.W.T. residential school grave exhumed, child's remains repatriated to family
items.description: The grave of a residential school victim was exhumed, and the child's remains were returned to her home community. Five-year-old Alma Beaulieu died at St Joseph's school in 1944.

items.title: Federal budget cuts $2.7 billion in international assistance
The Alluring Mysteries of BC’s Humpback Whales
items.description: As their numbers grow, so do deadly human encounters. Researchers are fascinated by their songs, sexuality and collective creativity.

items.title: Is there any point in getting a flu shot that's mismatched to the virus? Here’s what the science says
items.description: Some scientists say this year's flu shot isn't well matched to a key strain that could spread widely in the months ahead. So, is there still a point in getting it? Medical experts say: absolutely. Here’s why.
